title: Ted Brown (American football)
text:
Thomas Edward "Ted" Brown (born February 15, 1957) is a former American college and professional <a href="American%20football">football</a> player who was a <a href="running%20back">running back</a> in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> (NFL) for eight seasons during the late 1970s and 1980s. Brown played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> for <a href="North%20Carolina%20State%20University">North Carolina State University</a>, where he was recognized as an <a href="All-American">All-American</a>. He was a first-round pick in the <a href="1979%20NFL%20Draft">1979 NFL Draft</a>, and played professionally for the NFL's <a href="Minnesota%20Vikings">Minnesota Vikings</a>. Brown's son, <a href="J.%20T.%20Brown%20%28ice%20hockey%29">J. T.</a> is a former <a href="NHL">National Hockey League</a> player.
Early years.
Brown was born in <a href="High%20Point%2C%20North%20Carolina">High Point, North Carolina</a>. He attended <a href="T.%20Wingate%20Andrews%20High%20School">T. Wingate Andrews High School</a>.
College career.
By the time Brown graduated from <a href="North%20Carolina%20State%20University">North Carolina State University</a> in 1978, he had set the <a href="Atlantic%20Coast%20Conference">Atlantic Coast Conference</a> career rushing record with 4,602 yards and the single game rushing record with 251 yards against <a href="Penn%20State">Penn State</a> in 1977. He was an All-ACC pick for all four years in college and a consensus <a href="All-America">All-America</a>n in 1978.
College statistics.
In 2013, Brown was inducted into the <a href="College%20Football%20Hall%20of%20Fame">College Football Hall of Fame</a>.
Professional career.
The Minnesota Vikings chose Brown in the first round (sixteenth pick overall) of the 1979 NFL Draft, and he played for the Vikings from to .
In December 1981, Brown accidentally shot himself while handling a loaded revolver. The injury required surgery to remove bullet and wood fragments from his upper thigh. There was a question of whether he would be able continue his career in football.
Brown was inducted into the <a href="North%20Carolina%20Sports%20Hall%20of%20Fame">North Carolina Sports Hall of Fame</a> in 1995.
Post-retirement.
After retiring from football, Brown became a juvenile probation officer in <a href="Saint%20Paul%2C%20Minnesota">Saint Paul, Minnesota</a>. His son, <a href="J.%20T.%20Brown%20%28ice%20hockey%29">J. T.</a>, played with the <a href="Minnesota%20Wild">Minnesota Wild</a> of the <a href="National%20Hockey%20League">National Hockey League</a>.
